Award.AwardTitle: Potential for adaptation, and its realization, in natural plant populations
Award.AbstractNarration:
The principles underlying the process of adaptive evolution are well established, and have been well tested in the laboratory and over short time periods in the field. However, we also know that the long-term rate of adaptation can be subject to additional processes. The primary objective of this research is to examine how a population's genetic variability affects the rate of adaptation over many generations, in the face of variation in environmental conditions and the depletion of that genetic variation by natural selection. Quantitative genetic experiments will be conducted in nature to assess potential and realized adaptation for three populations of the annual plant species, Chamaecrista fasciculata (partridge pea).

This research will establish an empirical basis for predicting rates of ongoing adaptation. Beyond their fundamental importance, rates of adaptation are now of urgent societal importance in the context of rapidly changing climate. This research will inform policy and efforts directed toward conservation of natural populations. Moreover, the project will contribute to development of scientific capability by involving undergraduate, graduate and postdoctoral scholars, including members of groups underrepresented in STEM fields.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research was designed to assess the capacity for ongoing evolutionary adaptation of three wild populations of the annual plant, partridgepea, which is native to much of eastern North America. Prior research has yielded ample evidence of past evolutionary divergence among wild populations of many species, and research on populations in artificial conditions has demonstrated
adaptation and trait change through time, in many cases focusing on adaptation attributable to spontaneous mutations incurred during that time course. In contrast, this study adopted a prospective approach, evaluating for each population the amount of genetic variation available to support future adaptation to conditions currently prevailing in their natal sites. This goal entailed a quantitative genetic approach to estimate the additive (heritable) genetic variance for fitness, where fitness is defined as the number of seeds an individual that starts as a seed eventually contributes to the population. In overview, quantitative genetics bases estimates of additive genetic variance for any trait on the resemblance between relatives with respect to that trait. For this study, formal genetic crosses between plants were carried out by hand-pollination of plants collected as seeds in the wild and reared to maturity in a greenhouse. These crosses generated large sets of pedigreed offspring related as full-siblings and paternal half-siblings. These seeds were divided into subsets, and seeds were individually planted into the three natal sites, respectively (near Cottage Grove and Kellogg in SE Minnesota, and near Grinnell, Iowa), in randomized arrays in three successive autumns. The subsequent summer, fitness records (germination, survival and reproduction) were obtained for each planted seed. These data were the basis for estimation of the average fitness and the genetic variance of fitness for each population in each year. In each case, substantial, statistically significant additive genetic variance for fitness was found. These estimates were used to predict the magnitude of evolutionary change in mean fitness due to natural selection; in two cases where populations were initially declining, the predictions indicated 'evolutionary rescue', i.e. adaptation sufficient to render self-sustaining a population that had been in decline. All nine predictions were compared to the realized evolutionary adaptation (i.e. the actual genetically based change in average fitness) between generations; close correspondence was found in several, but not all, cases. Thus, this study has demonstrated the potential for predicting future adaptation, as well as limits of prediction. The finding of genetic capacity for ongoing adaptation does not necessarily indicate that populations will adapt to rapidly changing environments at rates that will ensure their persistence; this is a matter for further investigations that this approach would enable.

Intellectual merit of this study is multifaceted. The study serves as a 'proof of concept' of an approach to direct study of the process of adaptation enabling prediction of the rate of evolutionary adaptation. This approach could be adapted for study of adaptive capacity of other organisms, as well as study of the capacity for adaptation to change in specific aspects of environment, for example rapidly changing climate. Results of the study overturn a long-standing evolutionary expectation of little to no additive genetic variance for fitness, which was based on an assumption that incessant natural selection would drive this variation to nil by completely eliminating particular genetic variants (alleles) that compromise individual fitness. This study counters that assumption, showing that, from one year to the next, the genetic families differed in their average fitnesses relative to one another (statistical interaction between family and year). Thus, the findings indicate that natural selection does not strongly or consistently favor the same alleles from one year to the next.

Broader impacts of the study are also varied. Results of this study are being incorporated into recommendations to land managers of Minnesota state agencies and The Nature Conservancy about sourcing of seeds for prairie restorations. In particular, by demonstrating populations' capacity for ongoing adaptation, the study raises questions about the necessity or value of assisted migration for the persistence of wild populations, an idea that has been advocated strongly. The research fostered the development of scholar-practitioners of science including two postdoctoral fellows, two graduate students, ten undergraduates and a postbaccalaureate researcher. The research also motivated further development of the statistical approach to analyzing fitness records, aster modeling, with advances promulgated to the research community via online lecture notes, technical reports, and scripts underlying published analyses.
